definition:
By the [**]{} of a complex function $f$ in a domain $D$ of $\mathbb{C}$,
we every complex function $F$ which in $D$ satisfies the condition
$$\frac{d}{dz}F(z) = f(z).$$

-   If $f$ is a continuous complex function in a domain $D$ and if the
    integral $$\begin{aligned}
    F(z) := \int_{\gamma_z}f(t)\,dt\end{aligned}$$ where the path
    ${\gamma_z}$ begins at a fixed point $z_0$ of $D$ and ends at the
    point $z$ of $D$, is independent of the path $\gamma_z$ for each
    value of $z$, then (1) defines an analytic function $F$ with domain
    $D$. This function is an antiderivative of $f$ in $D$, at all points
    of $D$, the condition $$\frac{d}{dz}\int_{\gamma_z}f(t)\,dt = f(z)$$
    is true.

-   If $f$ is an analytic function in a simply connected open domain
    $U$, then $f$ has an antiderivative in $U$, the function $F$ defined
    by (1) where the path $\gamma_z$ is within $U$. If $\gamma$ lies
    within $U$ and connects the points $z_0$ and $z_1$, then
    $$\int_{\gamma}f(z)\,dz = F(z_1)-F(z_0),$$ where $F$ is an arbitrary
    antiderivative of $f$ in $U$.
